abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome rating of the
            Reengagement and Reform Support Project for Myanmar was
            judged to be highly satisfactory.  Additionally, the Bank
            performance and borrower performance were also rated highly
            satisfactory. The risk to development outcome is moderate.
            Several lessons were learned.  Implementation of complex
            operations requires a heavy commitment to coordination
            within the Bank, the bridge financier, and with the
            government. A systematic, written approach, which included
            arrears documentation clearance, was useful. Significant
            time was needed in walking the client through the process.
            Having a staff member close at hand and available was
            critical. In future reengagement cases, it might be useful
            to ensure that a decentralized task team leader is available
            for the government. Although expected outcomes were met, it
            would be appropriate to reevaluate continued progress over a
            longer period of time to minimize risks of backsliding.
            There is no easy solution to coordination challenges in
            managing the receipt of development assistance, but a
            generalized willingness among development partners to pool
            resources and approaches in order to reduce aid transactions
            costs, including via a shared program of prior actions is
            notable.  The urgent necessity of clearing arrears to IDA
            dictated the choice of instrument, and in particular the use
            of a single-tranche standalone DPO. This imposed limitations
            on the effectiveness of the instrument as a platform for
            sustained policy dialogue. A balance needed to be struck at
            the time of preparation between responding efficiently to a
            limited window of opportunity, versus establishing a longer
            term platform for policy dialogue. Thus the next and logical
            step would be for the preparation of a programmatic DPO
            series that might provide a more effective mechanism for
            engaging with the authorities on macroeconomic policy
            dialogue over a longer, multi-year reform period.
